Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as c1d019a6056a2a0ef50e577b3139ab5a8dc49355

I think several sensor-providing applications already add a type suffix to the D-Bus sensor name.  It is used to differentiate the various sensors from a single device.

For example, the D-Bus sensor names from the phosphor-regulators app for voltage regulator 'vdd1' are:
* vdd1_iout
* vdd1_iout_peak
* vdd1_iout_valley
* vdd1_pout
* vdd1_temperature
* vdd1_temperature_peak
* vdd1_vout
* vdd1_vout_peak
* vdd1_vout_valley

I see similar D-Bus sensor names from other sensor-providing apps, such as:
* ps0_temp0
* Ambient_2_Temp

Sensor names had to be unique in the Redfish Sensors output and in the GUI.  There can also be several sensors that fall into the same D-Bus sensor category, such as 3 regulator sensors dealing with voltage.

With this change, the type will be in the Redfish sensor name/URI twice:
* current_vdd1_iout
* temperature_vdd1_temperature
* voltage_vdd1_vout
* temperature_Ambient_2_Temp

This seems like confusing change for end users.

Perhaps an alternative would be to use a pattern/regex to infer the D-Bus sensor category from the Redfish sensor name, such as .*[tT]emp.* -> temperature, .*[vV]out* -> voltage.  I don't know; that might lead to some false positives.  Just trying to think of an alternative.

Another option would be to do a GetSubTreePaths call on "/xyz/openbmc_project/sensors".  That would be an extra D-Bus call unfortunately, but it should be a lot cheaper and more efficient than calling GetSubTree or GetManagedObjects.  You can then search through the returned list of just D-Bus object paths to find the full path to the specified sensor name and do a GetObject on that.

I don't like the sensor type in there twice either.
E.g. 
temperature_Ambient_2_Temp
temperature_vdd1_temperature

I don't see any documentation in 
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Sensor/Value.interface.yaml
around sensor naming, if we did go down this road, we need some. 
E.g. "the sensor name should be lower case and not contain the sensor type"?

As Shawn pointed out sensors had to be unique for Redfish Sensors output so why some contain the sensor type. :/

D-Bus: /xyz/openbmc_project/sensors/temperature/<sensor>
Redfish: /redfish/v1/Chassis/<chassis>/Sensors/<sensor>

There is information in the D-Bus path (e.g. this is a temperature sensor) that isn't in the Redfish path so including temperature in the sensor name makes sense but this is a big change and needs to be documented, should not just be a bmcweb change.

Another complication, as I noted above, is that some devices provide multiple sensors that fall into a category.  A single voltage regulator may provide two temperature-oriented sensor values, 3 voltage values, 3 current values, etc.  So the sensor object path cannot be as simple as sensors/temperature/vdd1.

> This seems like confusing change for end users.

The URI isn't for end users.  Users should be relying on "Name", which through this patch remains the same, and user facing.  Also, in terms of it being confusing, the "vdd" portion comes from the naming convention in the per-machine config files, so users that are confused are free to pick less confusing names (given that the dbus path is already namespaced).  This just makes redfish expose more of the confusing dbus.

For the regex stuff, that scares me a little trying to keep that both correct and up to date with every possible naming convention, especially when users are free to pick their own.  If folks are using the URI ID for anything human facing in a non debug context, that's a bug in their implementation.

>   You can then search through the returned list of just D-Bus object paths to find the full path to the specified sensor name and do a GetObject on that.

This is almost exactly what the old code did and the reason it was very slow, because it had to pull hundreds of sensors just to find the one it was looking for.

> around sensor naming, if we did go down this road, we need some. 

I'm not quite following why this would be required.  The sensor "Name" isn't changing in this patch, only the URI and the associated "Id" both of which are under the direction of the Redfish implementation.  The fact that the URI even includes the name at all is an implementation detail, which we could debatably just base64 encode per the spec, but that seems unnecessarily pedantic for debug use cases.

I need to more clear with Name and Id and which Name (D-bus or Redfish) I am referring too. Tried to be more clear here. 

Redfish IDs can't be assumed in Redfish (e.g. the path could be /redfish/v1/Chassis/<chassis>/Sensors/1) and Redfish gives other fields to identify a sensor (unfortunately most of those other fields aren't implemented) and Redfish name is set to the Redfish Id currently.

With this change it looks like Redfish Id would be temperature_Ambient_2_Temp for an example sensor from above. 
And Redfish Name continue to be Ambient_2_Temp, which the GUI would use Name on the Table. I still think we need some rules in https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Sensor/Value.interface.yaml around D-Bus sensor names. Should the D-Bus sensor name contain the sensor type or not? If it doesn't then Redfish Name should probably also be temperature_my_sensor.

> Should the D-Bus sensor name contain the sensor type or not? 

I don't think we can specify this, as doing it would immediately break a bunch of systems, and one big use case for OpenBMC is "I want my naming to exactly match my old stack" which is why the name fields are free-form in the platform config.

Early in dbus-sensors, we shopped around the idea of "lets just lock down all the sensor names on a consistent algorithm" and that flew like a lead balloon.  Folks have strong opinions on naming that I don't think it's worth it as a community to try to solve.


> if it doesn't then Redfish Name should probably also be temperature_my_sensor.

I wouldn't be an advocate for that, because we (the bmcweb maintainers) are messing with a users intent if we change the "Name" property from what they gave us.  If a user wants their sensor to be called "Temperature at the north pole" they should be allowed to do that, otherwise we'll end up on santas naughty list.  In a more real case, if a user wanted a name in a totally different language, they could.

The downside here, is now these Redfish ids are a bit awkward, we for example are still going to put temp in the D-Bus sensor name (so we know the difference between vdd1_temperature and vdd1_vout) so then yeah, the ids will look like 

temperature_Ambient_2_Temp
or 
temperature_vdd1_temperature
which is a bit awkward but they are just Redfish ids, and they could be /redfish/v1/Chassis/<chassis>/Sensors/15

I am good here.

> which is a bit awkward but they are just Redfish ids, and they could be 
> /redfish/v1/Chassis/<chassis>/Sensors/15

We intentionally didn't go that route originally because if sensor 14 disappears, what was previously sensor 15 becomes sensor 14, which isn't the best for clients, and against one of the "should" statements in the redfish spec.

Yeah, temperature_vdd1_temperature is a little awkward.  (in a future patch) We could try to detect that case, and if the sensor name ends with with the type "temp" or "temperature" or something that matches the type, we could just omit it from the front of the ID.  That's getting to be a little overill for my tastes for something that isn't supposed to be user facing.

Regardless, I think we can close out this thread.

Would a compromise be to include a comma in between the sensor type and sensor name in the URI?

e.g.

temperature,vdd1_temperature
temperature,vdd1_temperature_peak
voltage,vdd1_vout
voltage,vdd1_vout_valley

I think that is fairly readable, delineating the type vs. sensor name.  It still provides the desired information and query reduction.

Sorry, in looking at the URI documentation, a comma is not a recommended character, so that is not a good suggestion.  But perhaps a period or tilde?


temperature~vdd1_temperature
temperature~vdd1_temperature_peak
voltage~vdd1_vout
voltage~vdd1_vout_valley

A comma would have to be escaped as %2C i'm pretty sure.  Tilde would also need escaped as temperature%7Evdd1_temperature, so both of those seem worse when we account for what the http rfc requirements.

Making done.  I'm happy to continue discussing, and there's for sure some avenues I'd like to try going down with trying to make this better.  Considering we can change the odata.id at any time, and it sounds like we have concensus, I think this can go forward.
I thought you said we should use the same code path for $expand and per item get.

I’m not sure I understand the question.  yes, in theory we could use the generic GetAll handler for the expand queries, but given your recent optimizations, I think they will result in more dbus calls, so I left the existing code.  In theory we could test if those performance increases are still needed, but I think it’d be better to push that to a later patch, given that this patch works fine and is an improvement for the non expand case.

The question is that, during the code review of memory expand codes, I went with GetAll for single item, GetManagedObjects for expand, you made a comment saying we should use the same code. So later I used GetManagedObjects for both case.

Now in this patch, you are changing sensor to the previous option.

This is inconsistent. So I was asking for an explanation: what's the right direction and why is that?

I don't recall that specific conversation, but it's possible that I misspoke, intended a difference or was plain wrong.  With that said, there's a few things that differentiate sensors from inventory.

1. There's realistically only 2 sensor producers, so it's a lot easier to make assumptions about what each implements compared to inventory, which has 10s of daemons implementing, not all upstream.  ObjectManager is a requirement in the sensor schema, it is not in the inventory schemas (well, until recently).
2. This patchset does use the same code for all the parsing routines.  There is almost no duplication in the construction of the json object for sensor versus not.  The only primary additive difference is the code to actually do the GetAll call.
3. This common code is used to construct 3 different schemas (Sensors, Power, Thermal), so in comparison to inventory, which has lots of code with very little reuse between daemons, as well as many more redfish routes to service in the long run (maybe 12 different inventory schemas?), duplication in sensor code doesn't lead to a large difference in binary size.

Once we've made the prerequisite patches required for your Memory efficiency patch, lets take a look at it again and like I said before, it's quite possible I made a mistake about the amount of duplication between the inventory schemas.

Do you need any telemetry changes here? Can that be quick part of the test?

E.g.  

/redfish/v1/TelemetryService/MetricDefinitions/Altitude
{
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/TelemetryService/MetricDefinitions/Altitude",
"@odata.type": "#MetricDefinition.v1_0_3.MetricDefinition",
"Id": "Altitude",
"IsLinear": true,
"MetricDataType": "Decimal",
"MetricProperties": [
"/redfish/v1/Chassis/chassis/Sensors/Altitude/Reading"
],
"MetricType": "Numeric",
"Name": "Altitude",
"Units": "m"
}

This was a good callout, and definitely revealed some bugs.  One of the bugs I fixed in this patch I'm pretty sure is already a bug on master to do with MetricReport on SensorCollection items, but it's resolved in this patch.  I've added my test cases to the commit message, and they're now passing.
Note to the reviewers, we can't use sdbusplus::message::object_path here, because sensors have different escaping rules.
Just a rebase.  No need to re-review yet.

FYI, I think this was a bug on existing master.  SensorCollection didn't include the unit, and this was expecting a uri like

/redfish/v1/Chassis/my_chassis/Sensors/my_sensor/temperature

which doesn't match what the current URIs are.

Hi Ed, I am bit late but Just need clarification on this. Is it required to prefix with Sensors for each sensor name while using GET method from Redfish. Its like misleading sensor name to the user I feel. 
Ex:  "Id": "Sensors_Core_25_CPU1",
But while patching the sensor from Redfish, user has to remove the prefix (Sensors_) to patch value for actual sensor name.

Patch Body: 
{    
    "Id": "Core_25_CPU1",   --> removed prefix Sensors_
    "Reading": 27.0
}

> Hi Ed, I am bit late but Just need clarification on this. Is it required to prefix with Sensors for each sensor name while using GET method from Redfish. Its like misleading sensor name to the user I feel. 
> Ex:  "Id": "Sensors_Core_25_CPU1",
> But while patching the sensor from Redfish, user has to remove the prefix (Sensors_) to patch value for actual sensor name.
> 
> Patch Body: 
> {    
>     "Id": "Core_25_CPU1",   --> removed prefix Sensors_
>     "Reading": 27.0
> }

That seems like a problem.  Let me take a look.

For all the sensors, behavior is same. We have remove the Prefix (Sensors_) and need to patch.
Example:
https://<BMC-IP>/redfish/v1/Chassis/<Baseboard>/Sensors/temperature_Core_25_CPU1
Body:
{    
    "Id": "Core_25_CPU1",
    "Reading": 26.2
}

Can you take a look and see if: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/59027

Fixes your problem?
